question: Question_07_(a)
sols:
Multiplying by any non-zero integer (other than 1 or -1) will do the
trick. For example, multiplying by 2 gives the map

\begin{align*}
f: \mathbb{Z} &\to \mathbb{Z}\\
n &\mapsto 2n
\end{align*}

\textbf{Proof:} \emph{recall that this question didn't ask for a proof,
just the answer. Since the proofs are of a difficulty that you are
expected to be able to handle in this course, we present them here for
completeness.}

The function is injective since

\[2n = 2m \iff n = m\] and is not surjective since clearly no odd
integer will be in the image of the function $f$.
hints:
Recall that injective means that different integers have to be mapped to
different integers and not being surjective means that there must exist
some integer which is not in the image of the function $f$.
